9E62B8A87676404FA9E337FF77B2508F.description:
Draw conclusions based on hazard identity and physical environment to develop a scene
control plan.

66C89A8F520F410AACCD138B2DCD1147.description:
Classify material and summarize response measures that should be taken with a CBRNE
incident.

7A5B8D5257BB40B18CBB1495DC13C14F.description: Cite evidence and evaluate warning signs of CBRNE incidents.

D9EC549557A440CFAA1FE3B8699163D1.description:
Implement self‐protective measures (e.g., shielding, time, distance) based on type of TRACEM
incident.

EB529FF55FE84FC7B5E543CE7D24B660.description:
Summarize the types of thermal, radiological, asphyxiation, chemical, etiological, mechanical
(TRACEM) agents, behaviors, hazards and harm.

2A4BD2C5B1514E3583AD3E903BF97B73.description:
Identify possible targets and outcomes of CBRNE attacks and procedures to prevent and
mitigate the threat.

9C251E4064D4407BA2DA8E52F7BED155.description:
Hazardous Materials: Identify and describe procedures for reacting to a chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and
high‐yield explosive (CBRNE).

C64C5F567FF243CC88C6919E3AD6F3D4.description: Use intelligence to develop a threat and vulnerability assessment against a target.

DEF2C7A4ACCD4E49A406EE9F88495F50.description:
Describe strategies used to gather and evaluate domestic and international intelligence
information.

F2FAE13F240B449EB7EB1DC7FF78A3C1.description:
Identify and describe barriers to the gathering and sharing of intelligence by agencies and the
role of the Director of National Intelligence.

EA71B3CBAD554A0D929C4BBC2DCE9EB1.description: Describe the local, state and federal agencies involved in intelligence gathering.

576A687AF30F4126AEBA06DA16066025.description:
Apply legal issues related to intelligence‐gathering activities to prevent domestic and
international terrorism (e.g., Patriot Act, homeland security, presidential directives).

57E25091B28E48C5A137F2EA29667B61.description: Intelligence Gathering: Describe intelligence‐gathering activities on threat analysis.

55AA8B39E911479497EFE8E325E8CAB9.description:
Implement an emergency operations plan in response to an attack on infrastructure or
borders.

87821F52F2D24178B953291EE0F7527C.description: Describe local, state and federal agencies that protect the nation’s infrastructure and borders.

4D033280F70543ECBE39450BA1912B9C.description:
Describe the National Infrastructure Protection Plan (NIPP) and the role of the emergency
responder.

CEBEA5AEF19840DA8BD34B03E6D7359C.description: Identify techniques to protect and secure infrastructure and borders.

196AC1E4C32C4C178EFA0335832CB903.description:
Identify major points of vulnerability in the nation’s transportation, agriculture, food, water,
energy and communications infrastructure and borders.

FE1F8076F03C4A38A633876F80A8DBEE.description: Infrastructure and Border Protection: Describe the elements of national infrastructure and border protection.

509BA2BF31F74808A8593FFD47437B42.description: Compare and contrast the roles of the National Guard and military in responding to disasters.

EBFF9511ADFB426A80D31A8F679C8E09.description:
Summarize the procedures necessary for a local entity or state to obtain federal assistance in
a disaster situation.

2180488DCA9A470DA456F6E26DDFA305.description:
Identify and describe the role of the emergency management agency director in developing a
community emergency response plan and coordinating a response to a disaster.

4A4B94481966462CBF9D243317622ED0.description:
Describe the purpose for non‐governmental organizations (NGOs) in responding to emergency
incidents.

DF2C6AF82DDF4F4DA3A26739C4FA2141.description:
Describe the purpose of interagency and intergovernmental collaboration in responding to
emergency incidents.

D6B774A4EBAF47C88B88D9F4534FA485.description:
Compare and contrast responding to a terrorism‐created crime scene and a non‐terrorism‐
related crime scene.

27321E503C994492928A95A6157EAC8A.description:
Critique communication issues, procedures and interoperability among all homeland security
agencies.

864165C7F16F487BA038D176D25757E9.description: Describe the chain of command and hierarchy among all homeland security agencies.

05E595C3D1E5484688F75D68C174C89A.description:
Summarize the roles, duties and strengths of local, state and federal agencies involved in
homeland security.

820AFBE9E748401EB8534A8C81F514D6.description:
Analyze the types, modes of operation and tactics of terrorist organizations, both foreign and
domestic.

23E35718E7A94AAF87C6FAB6A3B27007.description:
Terrorism and Disaster Preparedness: Analyze terrorism, human trafficking and disaster preparedness and the role of homeland
security in prevention, mitigation, response and recovery.

D6E04E7239E84EC3A347D1E88B9CBCE2.description:
Homeland Security: Learners apply principles of the National Response Framework to protect critical infrastructure
from natural disaster and terrorism events through the all‐hazards approach of emergency
management; incident command; intelligence gathering; vulnerability assessments; emergency
planning; and chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and high yield explosives (CRBNE)
preparedness.

0731558626164D6FA480C8B3A995D0C8.description:
Discuss the fire department’s driving training program and the critical aspects of NFPA 1451
Standard for a Fire Service Vehicle Operations Training Program explaining the emergency
response in fire apparatus and personal vehicles.

57E75CFF99E140E2AD38C2376108CEF9.description:
Discuss the fire department’s driving training program and the critical aspects of NFPA 1451
Standard for a Fire Service Vehicle Operations Training Program explaining the laws and
liabilities, crash and injury prevention and crash review.

1E14F0608EA643F5B87F5831A080330C.description:
Discuss the fire department’s driving training program and the critical aspects of NFPA 1451
Standards for a Fire Service Vehicle Operations Training Program and explaining the
operating procedures, policies and procedures of the fire department.

310BB9873571408D842B6C735C27D3E8.description:
Specify Emergency Vehicle Requirements: The purpose of this standard shall be to specify the minimum requirements for a fire service
vehicle operations training program, including procedures for those members that drive or
occupy fire service vehicles, respond in private vehicles or unconventional means of
transportation and provide traffic control at the scene of an emergency.

F806D18146884B2C8CB0D0E5975076CD.description:
Demonstrate the ability to deploy, energize and monitor the system or equipment and to
recognize and correct system problems.

78AF75D05491495DAA88AD1C4492E124.description:
Demonstrate all fixed systems and equipment on the vehicle not specifically addressed
elsewhere in this standard, given systems and equipment, manufacturer’s specifications and
instructions and departmental policies and procedures for the systems and equipment, so
that each system or piece of equipment is operated in accordance with the applicable
instructions and policies.

DE189E544F69471988D3553E86DCEC49.description:
Explain the manufacturer’s specification and operating procedures and policies and
procedures of the jurisdiction.

568EA24D771F4AA0982B71AE89F484E5.description:
Operate Emergency Vehicle Fixed Systems: Operate all fixed systems and equipment on the vehicle not specifically addressed elsewhere in
this standard, given systems and equipment, manufacturer’s specifications and instructions and
departmental policies and procedures for the systems and equipment, so that each system or
piece of equipment is operated in accordance with the applicable instructions and policies.

31D7E164C07B4616A4F7EE846D222EDD.description:
Demonstrate the operation of a vehicle using defensive driving techniques under emergency
conditions, given a fire department vehicle and emergency conditions, so that control of the
vehicle is maintained.

2D03B1FF7BCA404DB0AA96595E983A3B.description:
Operate passenger restraint devices; maintain safe following distances; maintain control of
the vehicle while accelerating, decelerating and turning, given road, weather and traffic
conditions; operate under adverse environmental or driving surface conditions; and use
automotive gauges and controls.

D722E7A566A6484B8D8D9F6D892E900E.description:
Explain the effects on vehicle control of liquid surge, braking reaction time and load factors;
the effects of high center of gravity on roll‐over potential, general steering reactions, speed
and centrifugal force; applicable laws and regulations; principles of skid avoidance, night
driving, shifting and gear patterns; negotiation of intersections, railroad crossings and
bridges; weight and height limitations for both roads and bridges; identification and
operation of automotive gauges; and operational limits.

C6FDE3B7626E48FC92AAB066D345DA59.description:
Emergency Vehicle Defensive Driving Techniques: Operate a vehicle using defensive driving techniques under emergency conditions, given a fire
department vehicle and emergency conditions, so that control of the vehicle is maintained.

5147C233CE6242618AFE03CDD17481AB.description: Perform the ability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance.

FE6BDF9796AF43129DBE01048EBC83B8.description:
Explain the maneuver of a fire department vehicle in areas with restricted horizontal and
vertical clearances, given a fire department vehicle and a course that requires the operator to
move through areas of restricted horizontal and vertical clearances, so that the operator
accurately judges the ability of the vehicle to pass through the opening and so that no
obstructions are struck.

76CC4CB9CE1F4C4896E06DB89744C7F9.description:
Discuss the vehicle dimensions, turning characteristics, the effects of liquid surge, spotter
signaling and principles of safe vehicle operation.

2C6E67BDCBD142C59F0F0AE2DA3B56B9.description:
Maneuver an Emergency Vehicle in a Restricted Space: Maneuver a fire department vehicle in areas with restricted horizontal and vertical clearances,
given a fire department vehicle and a course that requires the operator to move through areas
of restricted horizontal and vertical clearances, so that the operator accurately judges the
ability of the vehicle to pass through the openings and so that no obstructions are struck.

BFFD915751484DA8995A56943A1F1445.description: Demonstrate the capability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance.

F3EC9719C5384CEFA99C1785A9097340.description:
Demonstrate the ability to maneuver a vehicle around obstructions on a roadway while
moving forward and in reverse, given a fire department vehicle, a spotter for backing and a
roadway with obstructions, so that the vehicle is maneuvered through the obstructions
without stopping to change the direction of travel and without striking the obstructions.

46098AB9942E4C26BEB679D589D67742.description:
Explain the vehicle dimensions, turning characteristics, the effects of liquid surge, spotter
signaling and principles of safe vehicle operation.

AA90F081F6E040D4BCC94D982C95E67C.description:
Turn an Emergency Vehicle: Turn a fire department vehicle 180 degrees within a confined space, given a fire department
vehicle, a spotter for backing up and an area in which the vehicle cannot perform a U‐turn
without stopping and backing up, so that the vehicle is turned 180 degrees without striking
obstructions within the given space.

44EC3D4998B9426C9553A1A65B6AD3A4.description: Demonstrate the ability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance.

4A697D00D1864083A613CA0216CF9315.description:
Perform the ability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance. Back a vehicle from a roadway
into restricted spaces on both the right and left sides of the vehicle, given a fire department
vehicle, a spotter and restricted spaces 3.7 m (12 ft) in width, requiring 90‐degree right‐hand
and left‐hand turns from the roadway, so that the vehicle is parked within the restricted areas
without having to stop and pull forward and without striking obstructions.

E53107B282D34F1781C502E16B3E383D.description:
Discuss the vehicle dimensions, turning characteristics, spotter signaling and principles of safe
vehicle operation.

6A7A8A8C571E4D53AB400C357D22B926.description:
Maneuver an Emergency Vehicle: Maneuver a vehicle around obstructions on a roadway while moving forward and in reverse,
given a fire department vehicle, a spotter for backing and a roadway with obstructions, so that
the vehicle is maneuvered through the obstructions without stopping to change the direction of
travel and without striking the obstructions.

1EA38DC7BBE247A2BF7510A5F6DB8D69.description: Demonstrate the ability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance.

29CE7AF5BCDD40429E826A53444EE513.description:
Perform the ability to use mirrors and judge vehicle clearance. Back a vehicle from a roadway
into restricted spaces on both the right and left sides of the vehicle, given a fire department
vehicle, a spotter and restricted spaces 3.7 m (12 ft) in width, requiring 90‐degree right‐hand
and left‐hand turns from the roadway, so that the vehicle is parked within the restricted areas
without having to stop and pull forward and without striking obstructions.

7EA87FC6C96245FB902C368FCF3775F5.description:
Discuss the vehicle dimensions, turning characteristics, spotter signaling and principles of safe
vehicle operation.

40DCA0BD2CAF4C7CAB96AACA8390FADE.description:
Back an Emergency Vehicle: Back a vehicle from a roadway into restricted spaces on both the right and left sides of the
vehicle, given a fire department vehicle, a spotter and restricted spaces 3.7 m (12 ft) in width,
requiring 90‐degree right‐hand and left hand turns from the roadway, so that the vehicle is
parked within the restricted areas without having to stop and pull forward and without striking
obstructions.

ACA3FD2CB0D04271AA084D9C8927D70D.description:
Demonstrate the ability to operate passenger restraint devices; maintain safe following
distances; maintain control of the vehicle while accelerating, decelerating and turning, given
road, weather and traffic conditions; operate under adverse environmental or driving surface
conditions; and use automotive gauges and controls.

15329128E7D64FEE9BFB35BF84D205F6.description:
Demonstrate the operation of a fire department vehicle, given a vehicle and a predetermined
route on a public way that incorporates the maneuvers and features that the driver/operator
is expected to encounter during normal operations, so that the vehicle is operated in
compliance with all applicable state laws, local laws and departmental rules and regulations.

820C1B5891ED4A2C922CD4CD19B3894C.description:
Describe the effects on vehicle control of liquid surge, braking reaction time and load factors;
effects of high center of gravity on roll‐over potential, general steering reactions, speed,
centrifugal force; applicable laws and regulations; principles of skid avoidance, night driving,
shifting and gear patterns; negotiating intersections, railroad crossings and bridges; weight
and height limitations for both roads and bridges; identification and operation of automotive
gauges and operational limits.

C99A95F4E33841A199A10626A96DF5F2.description:
Operate an Emergency Vehicle: Operate a fire department vehicle, given a vehicle and a predetermined route on a public way
that incorporates the maneuvers and features, specified in the following list, that the
driver/operator is expected to encounter during normal operations, so that the vehicle is
operated in compliance with all applicable state and local laws, departmental rules and
regulations and the requirements of NFPA 1500, Section 4.2: four left turns and four right turns;
a straight section of urban business street or a two‐lane rural road at least 1.6 km (1 mile) in
length; one through‐intersection and two intersections where a stop has to be made; one
railroad crossing; one curve, either left or right; a section of limited‐access highway that
includes a conventional ramp entrance and exit and a section of road long enough to allow two
lane changes; a downgrade steep enough and long enough to require down‐shifting and
braking; an upgrade steep enough and long enough to require gear changing to maintain speed;
and one underpass or a low clearance or bridge.

EE7001032D4D4B7DB55FB556950EEDE4.description:
Demonstrate the ability to use tools and equipment and complete all related departmental
forms.

7C6BDFD0A197418A89AA999E21D46189.description:
Discuss requirements for documenting maintenance performed and the importance of
keeping accurate records.

637283787D4B43FCBF0ECB01932DD273.description:
Document Emergency Vehicle Inspections: Document the routine tests, inspections and servicing functions, given maintenance and
inspection forms, so that all items are checked for operation and deficiencies are reported.

4AB56FBD563C4F7BA7A19567EE94F750.description:
Demonstrate the ability to use tools and equipment and complete all related departmental
forms.

DE6D66A9090F4E7C8446859466606F22.description:
Discuss requirements for documenting maintenance performed and the importance of
keeping accurate records.

1789F5C1051C4E3AA9DD88068903D2B1.description:
Document routine tests, inspections and servicing functions given maintenance and section
forms, so that all items are checked for operation and deficiencies are reported.

6BAE21BF5D594138A2A8D8B27F041E4D.description:
Demonstrate the ability to document any deficiency noted according to policies and
procedures.

0876A2800BC44430AF529F6F3B32E20F.description: Demonstrate the ability to recognize system problems.

43B0640789F04DB6942E62E68B725110.description: Demonstrate the ability to use hand tools.

CE72ACB5C97C4481A733C17DD39659C3.description:
List routine tests, inspections and servicing functions performed on the system and
components, given a fire department vehicle and its manufacturer’s specifications, so the
operational status is verified.

67F29FD8248A43B0AAFC22E0DCBD595E.description:
Test, Inspect and Service an Emergency Vehicle: Perform routine tests, inspections and servicing functions on the systems and components
specified in the following list, given a fire department vehicle, its manufacturer’s specifications
and policies and procedures of the jurisdiction, so that the operational status of the vehicle is
verified: battery(ies); braking system; coolant system; electrical system; fuel; hydraulic fluids;
oil; tires; steering system; belts; and tools, appliances and equipment.

8005B9930F8E4168904EEA8E1CBC78EF.description: Describe the purpose of a hazardous materials safety plan.

5DD6E4DD7F0A481DA985E3D2BE696638.description:
Identify sources of information on procedures for the safe cleanup, storage and disposal of
hazardous materials (e.g., CHEMTREC®).

38D376D9A69E4F87B6AB084770E98B1D.description: Read and interpret Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) forms and shipping documents.

98369B87BC0E45869CAA5A2A25C9E18E.description:
Identify and interpret hazardous material labels and placards using the U.S. Department of
Transportation (DOT) Emergency Response Guidebook.

6D0DFBE6A6574E1A9C1C45030850D65B.description:
Identify agencies that have resources to assist in hazardous material incidents (e.g.,
Emergency Management Agency [EMA], Environmental Protection Agency [EPA], Federal
Emergency Management Agency [FEMA]).

51A3CB42FE244A6CA501088D1501D1B2.description: Identify different forms of hazardous materials.

0A30A3DF86A3475380A3A4CA51BC3B71.description:
Hazardous Materials: Identify and respond to hazardous material incidents. (The firefighter candidate shall meet the
requirements defined in Ch. 5 [Core Competencies for Operations Level Responders] and Ch.
6.6 [Mission‐Specific Competencies Product Control] National Fire Protection Association
[NFPA] 472 [Standard for Competence of Responders to Hazardous Materials/Weapons of Mass
Destruction Incidents].)

864533139F97486CB4CB5687B02B36F8.description: Demonstrate the ability to operate a hose testing and nozzles and to record the results.

2D53BBBCBFC249DBB050F5068584EF97.description:
Describe the indicators that dictate any hose be removed from service and recording
procedures for hose test results.

E3A2440408124D7787DA8F9785A283EB.description: Discuss the procedures for safely conducting hose service testing.

C09BBA71704049A3997E4074E2D45E70.description:
Hose Maintenance: Explain the processes and demonstrate the procedures for inspecting, testing and placing a
hose out‐of‐service and completing documentation of test results. ([Fire and Life Safety
Initiatives, Preparedness and Maintenance] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001
Ch. 6.5.5)

511F250544534C29B761CDCDC2BB07FC.description: Demonstrate the ability to operate power plants, power tools and lighting equipment.

CBB0043639D14A0D98186B674D6A2BC4.description:
Demonstrate the ability to select correct tools, follow guidelines and complete recording and
reporting procedures.

D596E883F2F74AF2BD02ECC8259F9945.description:
Describe manufacturers’ and departmental guidelines for maintaining equipment and
documentation.

FA80E97466D346FD9EF96D0F2A472D03.description: Discuss the types of cleaning methods.

B2D29A7828A34F9FB4D807104DA3C7DB.description:
Tool Maintenance: Explain and demonstrate the cleaning and maintenance of power plants, power tools, lighting
equipment and hand tools. Complete appropriate maintenance records. ([Fire and Life Safety
Initiatives, Preparedness and Maintenance] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001
Ch. 6.5.4)

301387B2E5E545689007CD68A076057F.description: Demonstrate the ability to complete all related departmental forms.

89C4EFF657E0427E991A2031067EB544.description:
Perform the ability to detect hazards and special considerations to include in the pre‐incident
sketch.

BDC99439554D415380DB2E9A26FAFBBD.description:
Demonstrate the components of fire suppression and detection systems and sketch the site,
buildings and special features.

905A016997014E589C7ADECDF0BACD50.description:
Explain the departmental requirements for a pre‐incident survey and form completion and the
importance of accurate diagrams.

7769DD254396487DA4C6964312E2266B.description:
Discuss the common symbols used in diagramming construction features, utilities, hazards and
fire protection systems.

F91F38F63C634C77ADF1A30F9FC9C3A5.description: Discuss the fundamentals of fire suppression and detection systems.

80386C80FB2E4F99A798D29FBA041023.description: Describe the source of water supply for fire protection.

FC5AB37F46CE47C383CC1335C79C0AE2.description:
Safety Inspection: Explain the procedures for conducting a pre‐incident survey and prepare a pre‐incident report,
use appropriate forms, prepare a diagram of the structure (using common symbols to designate
the water supply, fire detection and suppression systems, construction features and utilities)
and identify special features and hazards associated with the structure. ([Fire and Life Safety
Initiatives, Preparedness and Maintenance] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001
Ch. 6.5.3)

E4615C5225984FFFBF6BBC91FF7CDE6E.description: Demonstrate the ability to document presentations and to use prepared materials.

5411837F4CC348BA9DDCF67E1ABBBF1D.description:
Discuss basic presentation skills and departmental standard operating procedures for giving
fire station tours.

F666969647FE4E7382EF2EAF307BB8F4.description: Describe parts of informational materials and how to use them.

8B50AD2BBFB04D1AA0127A7EF05F2C45.description:
Community Outreach: Discuss the basic presentation skills and knowledge requirements needed for conducting a
safety presentation using prepared materials. Demonstrate a safety presentation to a small
group of people during a station tour. ([Fire and Life Safety Initiatives, Preparedness and
Maintenance] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 6.5.2)

8513E175E17641E3B01355FA33E66504.description:
Demonstrate the ability to complete forms, recognize hazards, match findings to pre‐
approved recommendations and effectively communicate findings to occupants or referrals.

8791A477D2D74D2E954C46EF8591CF24.description:
Explain the importance of public safety survey and public fire education programs to a fire
department’s public relations and the community, including referral procedures.

261C372864374EB0809A946BABD95D0C.description: Discuss the common causes of fire and their prevention.

33EF6A6EE4FB4EEEA35C324D8E3FA212.description:
Fire Prevention: Explain current programs and procedures that target reducing fires and life safety hazards
through inspections, education and public relations. Prepare a fire safety survey on an occupied
structure, generating recommendations for reducing possible hazards. ([Fire and Life Safety
Initiatives, Preparedness and Maintenance] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001
Ch. 6.5‐6.5.1)

046C4F071E1B492A868571571F73232B.description: Assist a rescue team as a member, when assigned.

5A3FE8E8D5E74DEEA636922AC5C71D2F.description: Demonstrate how to set up effective public barriers.

C9D8B943656D4E3DA6F4A6AE49E67CB6.description: Demonstrate how to identify and retrieve various types of rescue tools for technical rescues.

0D78E5E14E9E4A648F334F6D4A79C0C8.description:
Choose and apply techniques for removing vehicle roofs, doors, windshields, windows,
steering wheels and columns and dashboards.

A005AB4FBEE34E2FBA5299DA765CE2E7.description: Demonstrate the usage of cribbing and shoring materials.

E8F92863010644ED87FC894CA3628215.description: Demonstrate how to operate hand and power tools used in forcible entry of vehicles.

E89C4FA5A15841DDB924501D6BF700BE.description: Discuss the tools used for technical rescue and their uses, including good practice.

098CD498F4B84034AEC674E519A00EB7.description: Discuss the hazards associated with technical rescues.

3DB451287125411CB8DA39B56EAF710E.description: Describe the firefighter’s role at technical rescue operations.

D825C1F91D86453EB87AE6630F2AA6B4.description:
Discuss the safety procedures, uses and limitations of hand and power tools used for
extrication.

BDE8566552A94554A3B193D17A68A018.description: Discuss the dangers associated with vehicle components and systems.

3BD61321F6B74F3F89A01CA3BCF12D63.description: Discuss the points of strength and weakness of an automobile body.

8655A1CC8FB24733B027D2A32E4A8926.description: Describe the fire department’s role at a vehicle accident.

FF3162B9EB634A2E9FC2C8456AF469C6.description:
Vehicle and Equipment: Use
Explain and perform assessing scene safety and stabilization of a vehicle involved in an
accident; assessing the vehicle's strong, weak and access points; using extrication tools and
equipment to remove vehicle components to disentangle a victim; and assisting a technical
rescue team by retrieving equipment and/or tools and recognizing inherent hazards associated
with various types of rescues. ([Rescue Operations] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA]
1001 Ch. 6.4‐6.4.2)

4F4171606EC34FF6A2D60BABAC189470.description:
Demonstrate the ability to locate the fire origin area, recognize possible causes and protect
the evidence.

E25421E546BA4DB3A3DE5C68454CA087.description:
Describe the effects and problems associated with removing property or evidence from the
scene.

84800B3ADE26421A889AD534937CA6F1.description:
Describe the role and the relationship of Firefighter 1, criminal investigators and insurance
investigators in fire investigations.

ADB538564387473198942384512009AA.description:
Discuss the methods to assess origin and cause, type of evidence and means to protect
various types of evidence.

A0B1A74FD50E4406AF8F5D4B3F19B80C.description:
Fire Investigation: Explain the measures taken and demonstrate the steps required for identifying the origin and
cause of a fire and protecting possible evidence of arson. ([Fire Ground Operations–Protecting
Evidence] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 6.3.4)

9EDFEFDE4D4A41DCBA81AF1B11CB011D.description:
Demonstrate the ability to assess cylinder integrity and changing cylinder conditions, operate
control valve and choose effective procedures when conditions change.

A98E5BB7274F47B18A994A38DB124433.description: Demonstrate the applicability of various techniques for water application.

9E2C8068A5504B1F8344DC84F68028B9.description: Demonstrate the ability to execute effective advances and retreat.

C07A43FAC1B141F7ABAFB274E0C893BA.description: Explain the alternate actions related to various hazards and when to retreat.

D5D2633C6D094992BD493C1A89D21CAA.description: Describe the valve types and their operation.

723F64F4B1984C0B987F5AE81B6D4757.description: Discuss what to do if the fire is prematurely extinguished.

B9B3BCBC5642451CAFC2EBC7BBC8A489.description: Discuss the water stream usage and demands for pressurized cylinder fires.

992A8A169FD84A518771017D5F7251C6.description:
List the methods for identifying content and how to identify safe havens before approaching
flammable gas cylinder fires.

DE2D1250BBC948B0B3C4318EF04F0B00.description: Describe the boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) signs and effects.

6F04A139F34340818A69352A14DA230F.description:

75245539771042668ACBD3AC4E3C978A.description: List and describe the principles, advantages, limitations and effects of hydraulic ventilation.

867B9BA89B384933990DECAF89E10504.description: List and describe the principles, advantages, limitations and effects of mechanical ventilation.

AE23733EB9D743448C7B2D75EC9DD606.description: List and describe the principles, advantages, limitations and effects of horizontal ventilation.

D9AC5191B2FC4E39B789B8D392A25D08.description:
Horizontal Ventilation: Identify the hazards associated with a structure needing horizontal ventilation and demonstrate
various types of horizontal ventilation using natural and mechanical means to remove smoke,
heat and toxic gasses from within the structure using appropriate tools, equipment and
procedures. ([Fire Ground Operations–Horizontal Ventilation] National Fire Protection
Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.3.11)

E5FEEFA17C8B46DF9764EF066B779E6B.description: Locate and suppress interior wall fires.

47BE593F728F4C52B2DD88408809FD46.description: Demonstrate the proper fire attack methods for a below‐grade‐level fire.

BED71610500A48A7AE9C0BAEA58FDD81.description: Demonstrate the proper attack methods for an above‐grade‐level fire.

6E8699A7E4DA46FA90CFC9976C86167C.description: Demonstrate the proper fire attack methods for a grade‐level fire.

AB48FE9351264243A049CA4A7341EAC5.description: Demonstrate the proper methods for coupling and uncoupling various size hose connections.

D09F89C381FC487E8A3B019F8D3589EC.description: Operate a charged hose line of 1½ inch diameter or larger while secured to a ground ladder.

9F70C4782EA04A7FB621623A56CAC86C.description: Demonstrate the proper methods for replacing burst or broken sections of hose.

9A67FE0303824F668C8782DE49FC8041.description: Demonstrate the proper methods for extending hose lines.

Demonstrate the proper procedure for advancing a 1½ inch or larger diameter hose down
stairways.

3F45CB96E7CD449683B23E54941157A2.description:
Demonstrate the proper procedure for advancing a 1½ inch or larger diameter hose up
stairways.

617A5F34D4AB46ACB28DBA1CDE424922.description:
Demonstrate the proper procedure for advancing a 1½ inch or larger diameter hose up
ladders.

2310D6DB5B7A4D9EBE52F7CAF6ACA4AF.description: Demonstrate the proper procedures for applying water using a combination fire attack.

9C898C404EB5483292BD41EB577241E9.description: Demonstrate the proper procedures for applying water using an indirect fire attack.

10B700501F4247778744D94B6323994B.description: Demonstrate the proper procedures for applying water using a direct fire attack.

A3EB4CF49B5C410597DBCC2BF81B04E7.description: Demonstrate the ability to properly open and close various smooth bore nozzles.

9FAED4FC0B464D6A9B6DBDBB2FEE01CF.description:
Demonstrate the ability to properly open, close and adjust nozzle flow and patterns on various
automatic and adjustable fog nozzles.

469FF2A1D51F409EA3A19081FD382178.description: Demonstrate the proper methods to prevent water hammer when shutting down nozzles.

719DF3AA84A84CF1B7B42982444B8A8B.description: Describe the proper methods for locating and exposing hidden fires.

74486417A94F41A2AE6486A674AA43AD.description: Describe the proper fire attack methods for a below‐grade‐level fire.

5CC4470B465C4CEA898BE195D24988E2.description: Describe the proper fire attack methods for an above‐grade‐level fire.

48756214B42A425DB2413D9DA142C116.description: Describe the proper fire attack methods for a grade‐level fire.

172850D6EABF460B9688A6AEDB526AAD.description: Describe the role of a backup team during an interior fire attack.

8156B92323E141E9B08A9AC58F59EFF7.description: Describe the proper placement application of a medium diameter (2½ inch) attach line.

278880F186C146108C8A3D91C5685193.description: Describe the proper placement and application of a small diameter (1½ to 2 inch) attach line.

F3F43D115CEA4EBEB09D85E5ABFF4EF1.description:
Describe common types of accidents or injuries and their causes that may occur on the fire
ground.

01ADF7B64EB34D668E67E78DC4B41FB2.description: List and describe the physical state of matter in which fuels are found.

3999916D586E4262A5A53B7CC5F45A5E.description:
List and describe the potential long‐term consequences of exposure to products of
combustion for a firefighter.

0B5A9247CF924584AB8C4CD9CBDB5F8A.description: Describe the basic principles of exposure protection.

9A48F0C336A240F49FD8077D3B93FBE5.description: Describe various dangerous building conditions created as the result of a fire.

FC6C557D5EE84786B5284DFACBC2263E.description: Describe the observable results of a properly applied fire stream.

8C695257145F40C1847C4DC69EE6C12F.description: List and describe the precaution to be followed when advancing hose lines to a fire.

BBDB1DD5140747B3827034F6B1D19F2C.description:
Describe the design, operation, nozzle pressure effects and flow capabilities of various types
of specialty nozzles.

3B50920F1BE54A98850F5B2D744A6D60.description:
Describe the design, operation, nozzle pressure effects and flow capabilities of various types
of smooth bore nozzles.

2B9E75D6CDD34A81B8CE78F18768CDE8.description:
Describe the design, operation, nozzle pressure effects and flow capabilities of various types
of fog nozzles.

ADB168F7D3D549F2B7D5134AB1A60488.description: List the various types of fire streams used for an interior fire attach.

5697AE6E4F5D4BBAAA459ACF856FA1DF.description:
Structure Fires: Explain procedures for and demonstrate how to deploy, extend and replace attach lines; enter
a structure using various entry points; control and extinguish a fire using effective water
application techniques for above grade and below grade fires; maintain team integrity; and
conduct an effective overhaul. ([Fire Ground Operations–Fire Control] National Fire Protection
Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.3.10; Note: National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1403,
Standard on Live Fire Training Evolutions, applies.)

E45E5B8FEE934200A921D3F9CD27D018.description: Demonstrate the proper techniques for assessing the tenability of a given area.

D16B5750F89344B69868D1110BBD5221.description: Demonstrate a rescue of a victim with no respiratory protection.

B5EA97ED3A90493DA2845886B6EEE32A.description: Demonstrate a rescue of a firefighter with a nonfunctioning SCBA.

E7EB33965CD1497D87287E03B7EA2451.description: Demonstrate a rescue of a firefighter with a functioning SCBA.

F58E849C520740DABE5DCBD66EE5498B.description: Demonstrate the proper placement and use of ladders during rescue operations.

E11B2E4223144DAD849B0C48D6C45AFC.description:
Demonstrate the various methods for maneuvering through restricted openings while wearing
a self‐contained breathing apparatus (SCBA).

94E5C1C4F173429C8FEC28F79A0A368E.description:
Describe various methods and carries used to remove victims from a structure, on various
floors, during search and rescue operations.

58A80B868DF64C438714A49FF953F805.description: List and describe various methods to locate victims during a search and rescue operation.

C052215A5568461E99F4F58244D9A70F.description:
List and describe each team member’s roles and goals during a structural search and rescue
operation.

DE9B930DA95E497C988E821E13E85C3C.description: Describe the proper techniques to conduct a secondary search.

3BAAF65D12B24DBF8DD6BA9A84B640FD.description: Describe the proper techniques to conduct a primary search.

C2AC07FA03AB413E93C85F4FEFAD2BD8.description: Describe methods to determine if an area is tenable and safe for interior operations.

D261238D4DA44059A9B0B34856A3D715.description:
Describe the physiological effects of operating in obscured conditions and ways to manage
them effectively.

70B799E26C6F48EB9FFBC1E6DA52D96B.description:
Describe the proper placement of ground and aerial ladders during structural rescue
operations.

13F11C5AB36040AAAC2805095CDC61D7.description:
List and describe the proper use of forcible entry tools used during structural rescue
operations.

B03572B47904442091ECE73BCD7203A3.description:
Search and Rescue: Explain the methods for and demonstrate entering a structure using various entry points,
performing a comprehensive primary search and rescue/removal of a victim found in an
obscured visibility environment and, when appropriate, conducting a secondary search while
using appropriate tools and equipment. ([Fire Ground Operations–Search and Rescue] National
Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.3.9)

9821915A4B0A4D1F99F131DD2E8DC3B7.description:
Operate hose lines and other water application techniques for maximum penetration and
search for and expose hidden fire.

4CE9D3A9EF9B4378B0AF06B4FFFFCDA8.description:
Assess fire, heat and smoke patterns for determination of fire origin while protecting physical
evidence and evaluate for complete extinguishment.

94D77F2982F04B56827DCF1D3C4E6E42.description:
Search for hidden fire, break up materials using hand tools, apply water streams and evaluate
for complete extinguishment.

1DC02BF570F046AFB87C9895FF220C1B.description:
Perform the ability to recognize inherent hazards related to the materials configuration and
operate hand lines and master streams.

D68F83FFB35D4F7C9E8FE11AF9B5A96D.description:
Disclose obvious signs of fire origin and cause and list the techniques for preserving fire cause‐
related evidence.

47ADB3C4B12E4150970CCC16DA1A9606.description:
List the hazards (e.g., collapse, toxic fumes, hazardous materials) that may be found during
fires in buildings, storage facilities and containers.

43D1B829EC7C4B1ABDE0E76E91F1DCD8.description: Describe the methods used for water application for exposure protection and fire suppression.

870465BB819C4CFF9EE3D113B6EBBBD3.description:
List methods, along with the tools required, used to break up various types of materials and
the difficulties related to complete extinguishment.

27EB962D967C4C868ED250E34FA9F862.description:
Explain how each extinguishing agent should perform to extinguish different materials and
material configurations.

FAD064BF979240E1B968DA7A18A708E4.description: Describe the dangers of a collapse associated with stacked and piled materials.

E3FEA2707666430BBD4358AABFEB8FE8.description:
Discuss types of attack lines and water streams appropriate for attacking stacked piled
materials and outdoor fires.

43D067E55E364889A604F3A30F771449.description:
Inspecting Materials Storage: Explain the methods and demonstrate the procedures for identifying hazards of stacked or
stored materials on fire, controlling and extinguishing fires involving Class A stacked/stored
materials using hand lines and master stream devices, overhauling stacked and stored materials
addressing all safety concerns, locating fire origin and cause and preserving evidence. ([Fire
Ground Operations–Stacked Class A Fires] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch.
5.3.8)

938D7138BDE048639EF8F7300A4229CA.description: Identify dangerous conditions created during a vehicle fire.

879AFEEE435347F486748E4E1E3BD54A.description: Identify a vehicle’s fuel type and use proper procedures for controlling fuel leaks.

5BAFAB57A21C4E29BA3220C2113404E6.description: Access all locked and unlocked compartments to expose and extinguish hidden fires.

549D9343FBE84DD4940FBBACB833ADB0.description:
Perform the proper procedures while advancing a 1½ inch or larger diameter attack line,
operating the nozzle patterns for maximum effectiveness and extinguishing the vehicle fire
while maintaining flash fire protection.

69D7F69405244D318F1DFEEB9AB81609.description: List procedures for conducting a safe and effective overhaul after extinguishing a vehicle fire.

FCC551B9C5DB4CD7A43A941965FA60F0.description:
Describe how to gain entry into locked trunks, engine compartments and passenger
compartments.

9B8D601C13FE43C0AFC188DDF01C0BEE.description:
Disclose the types of injuries associated with extinguishing vehicle fires along with procedures
for avoiding these injuries.

5821189C265943589C3B06D1E497816E.description:
Identify types of alternative fueled vehicles and list the hazards associated with each vehicle
type.

3A0B4EA6C92D4A13913D61A194DB6806.description: Describe the desired observable results of a properly applied fire stream to a vehicle fire.

6B05742AC651419083CCA46617C02E96.description:
List the dangerous conditions created during a vehicle fire, along with the precautions taken
when advancing hose lines towards these types of fires.

AC42FDB377324DFA83909C873CB280D2.description: Convey the principles of fire streams as they relate to fighting vehicle fires.

D35935E1352D48C88299E9244812B0AF.description:
Vehicle Fires: Explain knowledge of and demonstrate the performance required to identify multiple hazards
associated with vehicle fires and use the correct techniques for controlling and extinguishing a
vehicle fire. Force entry into all locked compartments. ([Fire Ground Operations–Vehicle Fires]
National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.3.7)

43590721E77440CC813F60FDA0AAD25B.description: Climb and leg lock an extension ladder and work with a tool.

9CF65789F669408BA095A91CB135DE72.description: Climb and leg lock an extension ladder.

A0D33BB951F649DBB0BBB18519F16C9D.description:
Select the correct length extension ladder for a given height and properly place the ladder
addressing and avoiding safety hazards.

556AB5FBAEAC43E69FA08DB67AAE2FEF.description:
Establish with certainty that a wall or roof will support a ladder and that the ladder is at the
correct climbing angle for the given task.

B0E18F23B89C45DE82A8B6C9B752BF86.description:
Demonstrate carries and raises for single and extension ladders along with extending fly
sections, assuring the fly section is locked.

A85CD0F250034E15B4BA65AB782E2CEB.description: Explain what constitutes a reliable structural component for tip placement.

C30B9DEEE85E48B9A6A46674FECF4B0E.description:
Describe the different climbing angles needed for safe completion of various tasks along with
extending fly sections, assuring the fly section is locked.

F6D0E418A53B461D8F90645C0B5517BD.description: Explain what constitutes a stable foundation for ladder placement.

97D6A11B320F44DFB5C480EF09573396.description: Explain the hazards associated with setting up ground ladders.

2B45B3A6738747CC94DCFC770A7CC7A9.description: List the parts of an extension ladder.

F70200ACF5674443AA127BD611183E41.description:
Ladders: Explain the knowledge needed and demonstrate the skills required to select, carry, place, raise,
extend, climb and work off of ladders. ([Fire Ground Operations–Ladders] National Fire
Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch.5.3.6)

CBAB80EFFE31446BABB56C2809BED929.description: Demonstrate methods to conserve self‐contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) air.

8D2DD707BEA44BA1AFE623BE11F94444.description:
Exit a hazardous area by searching for and finding a guide line then following the line to a safe
haven.

98F32A0CBDE543B5BC370F9B935ACD24.description:
Conduct a search, as a team member, in a vision‐obscured condition, using all available senses
to evaluate for hazards.

C7A800A3A4F046438B8AC8516989086F.description: List the elements that create and/or indicate a hazardous environment.

A4A6E0D5EB3D4DC6BC8645112A5409D4.description: Describe the emergency procedures for loss of air supply.

78FAC51E315443EEB7F442BEA4A88AFE.description:
Describe personnel accountability systems, emergency escape and what constitutes a safe
haven.

BE781E16E53A4385AC42751164EC6F49.description:
Define emergency radio traffic communication procedures and emergency evacuation
signals/methods.

D818F55D0FA6476796D023E577E89BCF.description:
Safe Egress: Demonstrate as a team how to safely exit a hazardous environment, with zero visibility
conditions, into a safe environment, without depleting your air supply and while maintaining
team integrity. ([Fire Ground Operations–Exit Hazardous Area] National Fire Protection
Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch.5.3.5)

1596383D59C04451AFEF1F3CCE44FB1A.description:
Demonstrate how to safely carry, operate and use common forcible entry tools to force entry
through doors, windows, walls and locks.

D01415366C6E4F11AEDED2919936478B.description: Convey dangers associated when forcing entry through doors, windows, walls and locks.

2D2CDE9FD7F2491886640BF5AC6B1C2E.description:
Explain the operation of a variety of doors, windows and locks used within the community or
service area.

6F51D521382B4F6A9154919FE45007C9.description:
List the basic construction of typical doors, windows and walls found within the community or
service area.

4F9FB3064AF44D269F1D01A40A1E42BD.description:
Entry Techniques: Identify common methods and perform forcible entry techniques through various types of
doors, windows, walls and the locking mechanisms using powered and non‐powered
equipment and tools. ([Fire Ground Operations–Forcible Entry] National Fire Protection
Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch.5.3.4)

584B7AA5266C4FF69A200EAAA5400BEE.description:
Demonstrate how to safely dismount an apparatus, don appropriate safety equipment for the
given situation and deploy traffic and scene control devices to protect the work area.

B4BA3AE14D3B41FEA056F047EC48F623.description:
Explain the procedures and use of different types of protective equipment available to ensure
the user’s safety, while operating at emergency scenes and work zone designations.

8D75C4FBE02A40648AAE7CA81C39C903.description:
Describe the proper procedures for dismounting a fire and EMS apparatus in traffic and at
other emergency and nonemergency scenes.

3984B79D495E448CBEE3E32F3D30BF3C.description:
Explain the potential hazards involved in operating at emergency scenes, including traffic
control, utilities and environmental conditions.

EB7069A2D8BA441883AD6182A302BBB7.description:
Demonstrate the proper use for each piece of safety equipment provided, including wearing
seat belts.

D10909CE2F43435CBC19B4D638313C1F.description: List the common types of PPE used while riding on a fire and EMS apparatus.

2328DBFCC49E47C2A9A0CC9FB6171E25.description: List the practices that are prohibited while riding a fire and EMS apparatus.

05D6421B59504444B920D2521B25511C.description:
Describe the hazards and ways to avoid hazards that cause accidents associated with riding a
fire and EMS apparatus.

B0FAD3520AA741DF939D456FED541763.description:
Discuss the mounting and dismounting procedures for riding a fire and Emergency Medical
Services (EMS) apparatus.

444F0C0595F54851A64E378C4DF30E26.description:
Don all personal protective clothing and equipment correctly within two minutes, with
breathing air and Personal Alert Safety System (PASS) device activated.

45603E87A49841D2BF289663857219D9.description:
Demonstrate emergency procedures taken in the event of a SCBA failure or air cylinder
depletion.

BC7F3D5F2A4946DF815F36B0B8371477.description: Replace a depleted air cylinder with a full air cylinder on a SCBA unit.

884BC961C9CE4F608410B4460A016F70.description: Demonstrate the ability to control breathing while breathing air from a SCBA unit.

BC79BCE8FF0141B4ADDA8736FD619F53.description:
Exit a restricted passage while wearing full personal protective equipment (PPE) and breathing
air from a SCBA unit.

581B6F2C2F6A42F29F52DA44C79F5D6C.description: List the physical requirements for wearing SCBA.

1B786EDF7B5748AC9F05CF630D8A807D.description: Describe the indicators for and discuss possible emergency procedures while wearing SCBA.

EB3C31C0600A4E6C9D38149244F4E558.description: Convey breathing techniques while wearing SCBA.

00C7CF79B4C141E68381640131560BB1.description: List and discuss the components that make up the SCBA assembly, including low air alarms.

5AE3B51284CE46498980504E28B9795C.description:
Self‐Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA): Explain knowledge of and demonstrate the ability to wear, operate and monitor air supply of a
SCBA; use emergency techniques, procedures and built‐in functions, including warning devices,
in case of equipment malfunctions or activation of low air alarm; exit a structure prior to air
cylinder depletion; wear protective equipment while mounting, riding and dismounting a fire
apparatus; and establish and work safely in designated work areas. ([Fire Ground Operations–
SCBA] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.3–5.3.3)

0FBBDAEEA6024445B839606641846604.description:
Demonstrate an emergency call for assistance and use alternative methods for requesting
assistance.

5F0E82264D0A45EAAFF81E65A1066D94.description: Discuss emergency communications procedures and emergency evacuation methods.

F54D99DD1DE74A61BF636453EC8070DD.description:
Perform the ability to operate radio equipment and discriminate between routine and
emergency traffic.

62B480ED149B432A9A31CF7F378307D2.description:
Discuss the departmental radio procedures and etiquette for routine traffic, emergency traffic
and emergency evacuation signals.

92EE708C5D8D452B9B7EF63C0F8504D8.description: Demonstrate the ability to operate fire station telephone and intercom equipment.

2D08101BDFE44A78A32FF229FFE3C248.description: Discuss the fire department procedures for answering nonemergency telephone calls.

C111CEAE493946EFA02698CFF2E5BF9F.description:
Demonstrate the ability to operate fire department communications equipment, relay
information and record information.

A3D4CE281E904AD1B26D170BB93BC526.description:
Explain the procedures for reporting emergency, departmental standard operating procedures
(SOPs) for taking and receiving alarms, radio codes or procedures and information needs to a
dispatcher.

EB6CCF838502473B85DCA6F16BB46ED1.description:
Communication: Explain the communication process and list different ways of communicating and initiating a
response. Demonstrate the use of basic fire department communication equipment to convey
emergency and nonemergency information with persons inside and outside of the department.
([Fire Department Communications] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.2‐
5.2.4)

B8711AEFA6EC494D81EE38FDDC915EC8.description: Locate and clarify information in department documents, standards and code materials.

472E0439313640DBAA213EF5E40178B7.description: Perform the ability to doff personal protective clothing and prepare for reuse.

FCB5D9EBDDE54C71A4BDB046A4382D70.description: Perform the ability to don personal protective clothing within one minute.

19B49539C5C74474842B4888208A79D8.description:
Personal Emergency Equipment: Demonstrate how to don and doff personal protective clothing, prepare clothing for reuse and
locate information using department documents along with standards and code materials.
([General Skills Requirement] National Fire Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.1.2)

F176D74B3EDD432C84981445CD834807.description:
Discuss the value of fire and life safety initiatives to support the fire department’s mission and
to reduce the line of duty deaths.

FDA6543C5F5049A497041731E2E6B12E.description: Discuss the role of other agencies as they relate to the department.

B0AF74234E6542E1A230F6464E38B551.description:
Explain the fire department’s standard operating procedures, rules and regulations as they
apply to firefighters.

5918685F454F469A9A7087453E72C1EC.description: Discuss the role of the Firefighter 1 within the organization.

8DFDF80E41BA4EB8A2C0FB886CE2B7E6.description: Describe the organization of the fire department.

057201756009491780229D60B9482EEF.description: State the mission of the fire service.

18CB37DFCDEF4BF4B1BE9DE5F7153671.description:
Discuss the critical aspects of the fire department’s member assistance program, the critical
aspects of NFPA 1500, Fire Department Occupational Safety and Health Program.

DFA740E8ED8948FD958AB0B6FF382878.description:
Organization and Mission: Explain the organization, mission statement, policies and procedures of a fire department and
explain the role of a Firefighter 1 within the organization. Communicate the value of fire and
life safety initiatives to reduce line of duty deaths and injuries along with the internal programs,
external agencies and documents addressing the well‐being of the Firefighter 1. Explain the
organization, mission statement, policies and procedures of a fire department and explain the
role of a Firefighter 1 within the organization. ([General Knowledge Requirements] National Fire
Protection Association [NFPA] 1001 Ch. 5.1.1)

AD2E524CC81445E1A928B25B154BD968.description:
Fire Science: Learners apply principles of firefighting to prevent and suppress fires. Knowledge of the science
of combustion; fire service structure and organization; life safety initiatives; communication;
and the use of fire apparatus, tools and appliances will be applied in fire suppression,
ventilation, hazardous materials containment and rescue.

5F1C641AEE1B4792B53E047CBA5AFE4D.description:
Participate in and document patient contacts in a field experience approved by the medical
director and program director.

7C7DC846B7A04AE19620B7F1B099F5E0.description:
Perform ten patient assessments in an emergency department, ambulance, clinic, nursing
home, doctor’s office, or on standardized patients if clinical settings are not available.

C8D1CDDAF8CE4613ABB454D88C8B26B1.description:
Observe emergency department operations for a period of time sufficient to gain an
appreciation for the continuum of care.

A173FB2943194292A5C5938C8E16CA1D.description: Complete at least ten hours of clinical and/or field experience.

06C8B13B48CA42DA82166B1DA6ADD564.description:
Complete all clinical and field requirements in accordance with Ohio Administrative Code
(OAC) 4765‐15‐05, EMT Curriculum, prior to receiving a certificate of completion.

B966173F511F46B1A8C394003559ACB9.description: Ensure the safety of the rescuer and others during an emergency.

C0A2387FAACF4E0D9745AB11976F8F31.description:
Serve as an entry‐level EMS team member on an emergency call with more experienced
personnel in the lead role and serve as a team leader following additional training and/or
experience.

38ED9E651B01470B87CCA3ECE9050BDE.description:
Perform a patient assessment and provide prehospital emergency care and transportation for
patient complaints (i.e., abdominal pain, abuse/neglect, altered mental status/decreased level
of consciousness, anxiety, apnea, ataxia, back pain, behavioral emergency, bleeding, cardiac
arrest, cardiac rhythm disturbances, chest pain, constipation, cyanosis, dehydration, diarrhea,
dizziness/vertigo, dysphasia, dyspnea, edema, eye pain, fatigue, fever, gastrointestinal [GI]
bleeding, headache, hematuria, hemoptysis, hypertension, hypotension, joint pain/swelling,
multiple trauma, nausea/vomiting, pain, paralysis, pediatric crying/fussiness, poisoning, rash,
rectal pain, shock, sore throat, stridor/drooling, syncope, urinary retention, visual
disturbances, weakness, wheezing).

A11B1AAB1CCF49158974BCC06A6123B4.description: Report and document assessment data and interventions.

E7CCD01B073441F09F2ECAF27EA9BD42.description:
Initiate basic interventions based on assessment findings intended to mitigate the emergency
and provide limited symptom relief while providing access to definitive care.

A82A6B199EFB4B47BC647B9A8BF2A27B.description:
Demonstrate professional behavior, including (but not limited to) integrity, empathy, self‐
motivation, appearance/personal hygiene, self‐confidence, communications, time
management, teamwork/diplomacy, respect, patient advocacy and careful delivery of service.

0DBA52F8E2474D5C888A2112F7A11653.description:
Safely and effectively perform psychomotor skills within the National Emergency Medical
Services (EMS) Scope of Practice Model and the Ohio Scope of Practice at the EMT level for
airway and breathing (i.e., orotracheal intubation of pulseless and apneic patients with
extraglottic or multilumen device, endotracheal suctioning through a stoma, positive pressure
ventilation, manually triggered ventilators, automatic transport ventilators, supplemental
oxygen therapy, constant positive airway pressure [CPAP] administration and management,
end‐tidal carbon dioxide [ETCO2] monitoring and detection, humidifiers, manually triggered
ventilators, automatic transport ventilators, partial rebreather mask, venturi mask),
assessment (i.e., blood glucose monitor and automatic blood pressure [B/P]), pharmacologic
interventions (i.e., assist patients in taking their own prescribed medications, administration
of over‐the‐counter [OTC] medications with medical oversight, oral glucose administration,
aspirin for chest pain, 12‐lead electrocardiogram [EKG] setup, application for electronic
transmission), medical/cardiac care (i.e., mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation [CPR],
assisted complicated delivery) and trauma care (i.e., spinal immobilization, cervical collars,
seated, longboard, rapid extrication, splinting, extremity, traction, pneumatic anti‐shock
garment [PASG], helmet removal, mechanical patient restraint, tourniquet).

13938D4DB6AD4229BE8FF2D8FA7C0F73.description: Communicate in a culturally sensitive manner.

972DDA149275461294166484EA06ADE3.description:
Perform a basic history and physical examination to identify acute complaints and monitor
changes and identify the actual and potential complaints of emergency patients.

073EE1187B684DC3A8C35D0917F93AC1.description:
Clinical Behavior/Judgment: Practice skills in the clinical and field experience requirements of the Emergency Medical
Technician (EMT) curriculum.

5F2DE3B0E7D54973957978EAEDEF2612.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the risks and responsibilities of operating
on the scene of a natural or man‐made disaster.

AA2BA55D3469439493A6F4927B48A75E.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the risks and responsibilities of operating
in a cold zone at a hazardous material or other special incident.

E1AF172BF10246AC92079E4CA7575E60.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on safe vehicle extrication and use of simple
hand tools.

1E5E10424A24454C961F0ADEA0A95F92.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on safe air medical operations and criteria
for utilizing air medical response.

D1C693015C6446F8A0BC418A64D1DAE4.description:
Apply simple depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on multiple casualty incidents,
including triage, performing, retriage, destination decisions and posttraumatic and cumulative
stress.

FC5A4EBC1FFF4951A1427DD34A0A03E5.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on multiple causality incidents, including
triage principles and resource management.

A9990B6108A34F4D86FFB2F0AF818179.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on incident management,
including establishing and working within the incident management system.

E70E43C06D35415FA5B9E33B5B73E4E0.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the principles of safely operating a
ground ambulance, including the risks and responsibilities of transport.

39961C54AC784E8BA9D27D23C74318BB.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the principles of safely operating a
ground ambulance, including the risks and responsibilities of emergency response.

E6AB05AA41D448E493B17A22C1CF2978.description:
Emergency Medical Services (EMS) Operations: Apply knowledge of operational roles and responsibilities to ensure patient, public and
personnel safety.

F721993AA7CB4EE8B0F72F4984BCD4B1.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the healthcare implications of patients
with special challenges, including abuse, neglect, homelessness, poverty, bariatrics,
technology dependent, hospice/ terminally ill, tracheostomy care/dysfunction, homecare,
sensory deficit/loss and developmental disability.

3F2E41FFC8FE4591BD0D31E5C5FE2F03.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on patients with special challenges on
recognizing and reporting abuse and neglect.

9EA58885971B4AB69C3BE71BEFA2E6F0.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on changes associated with
aging, psychosocial aspects of aging and age‐related assessment and treatment modifications
for the major or common geriatric diseases and/or emergencies, including cardiovascular
diseases, respiratory diseases, neurological diseases, endocrine diseases, Alzheimer’s and
dementia.

2250FC1C4D3943979A7972B2EBBD761B.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the impact of age‐related changes on
assessment and care in geriatrics.

1B457BAF458F4EDBBF987B65156F1B41.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on age‐related assessment
findings and age‐related and developmental‐stage‐related assessment and treatment
modifications for pediatric‐specific major diseases and/or emergencies, including upper
airway obstruction, lower airway reactive disease, respiratory distress/failure/arrest, shock,
seizures, Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and gastrointestinal disease.

D22FF0FCE3A746EABECC4D8CB69F5A33.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on age‐related assessment findings and age‐
related assessment and treatment modifications for pediatric‐specific major diseases and/or
emergencies, including upper airway obstruction, lower airway reactive disease, respiratory
distress/failure/arrest, shock, seizures and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

DDB9EF2E5E704DC8BDFC1DB934639C0F.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on neonatal care assessment
and management, including newborn and neonatal resuscitation.

AE8995560DAF4734B139FD6E85A13D2D.description: Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in newborn care and neonatal resuscitation.

6B4C038D4D6D439CA9E80303400A3494.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on obstetrics, including the
anatomy and physiology of normal pregnancy, pathophysiology of complications of
pregnancy, assessment of the pregnant patient, management of normal delivery, abnormal
delivery (nuchal cord, prolapsed cord, breech delivery), third trimester bleeding (placenta
previa, abruptio placenta), spontaneous abortion/miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy and
preeclampsia/eclampsia.

CA90CF3047B64CA49813155E71DDC605.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of a
normal delivery, vaginal bleeding in the pregnant patient, assessment of the pregnant patient,
management of normal delivery, recognition of abnormal delivery, placenta previa and
spontaneous abortion/miscarriage.

350683276A434C3DA9CD132CB39E9849.description:
Special Patient Populations: Apply a fundamental knowledge of growth, development and aging and assessment findings to
provide basic emergency care and transportation for a patient with special needs.

3C476B4ACA3A408AB8BF11E4196355DE.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge in the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of multisystem trauma and blast injuries.

3DBF6945AD9B4DA5986894376AE8A340.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
multisystem trauma.

32C00188190C49E7B385FE88F71ACEFE.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge in the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of environmental emergencies, including near drowning,
temperature‐related illness, bite and envenomation, dysbarism (high‐altitude, diving injuries),
electrical injury and radiation exposure.

11798345372D4E0BAC0A92A2CB62491F.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
environmental emergencies, including water and ice injury and temperature‐related illness.

6CC29F1878DC4687AA9FEC482F529B36.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge in the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of trauma in the pregnant patient, pediatric patient, geriatric
patient and the cognitively impaired patient.

52EADDF776A14C8096AAA98DEF659A0E.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
trauma in the pregnant patient, pediatric patient and geriatric patient.

5FC9C407756A4372B2D93B5F10DA553F.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of nervous system trauma, including traumatic brain injury and
spinal cord injury.

B00D832B1E3B460AAD5996634144D849.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on head, facial, neck and spine trauma,
including facial fractures, skull fractures, foreign bodies in the eyes and dental trauma.

E67AB0F30F1B45C7BBA10C60E74B1F69.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of head, facial, neck and spine trauma, including penetrating
neck trauma, laryngotracheal injuries and spine trauma.

9F79E84E9A6B4AB3B47F3F892698003F.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the recognition and management of
head, facial, neck and spine trauma, including life threats, head and spine trauma and
mechanism of injury.

41689D8948E045F39B538F06B819FA00.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on soft tissue trauma due to crush
syndrome.

23D6CCD3890C469D8A461E627584C53A.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of soft tissue trauma, including wounds (avulsions, bite wounds,
lacerations, puncture wounds, incisions) and burns (electrical, chemical, thermal, radiation).

80E695ACF068404B9F564C953BCA844F.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the recognition and management of soft
tissue trauma, including wounds, burns (electrical, chemical, thermal) and chemicals in the
eye and on the skin.

282E5E99E1BE496BA84A956F3D82A662.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge in the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of orthopedic trauma, including upper and lower extremity
orthopedic trauma, open fractures, closed fractures, dislocations, sprains/strains, pelvic

43905EE1ABE6424998201D231A59ACCC.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
orthopedic trauma, including open fractures, closed fractures, dislocations and amputations.

9EE36F90844042F2A46FBC1F82308F1A.description:
Apply fundamental depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the pathophysiology, assessment
and management of abdominal and genitourinary trauma, including solid and hollow organ
injuries, blunt versus penetrating mechanisms, evisceration, injuries to the external genitalia,
vaginal bleeding due to trauma and sexual assault.

F2ED9D67D71240F58B14C9DA037B221B.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
abdominal and genitourinary trauma, including blunt versus penetrating mechanisms,
evisceration and impaled object.

2BA62566912A48618AF88481DD08B667.description:
Apply fundamental depth, simple breadth of knowledge on chest trauma pathophysiology,
assessment and management, including blunt versus penetrating mechanisms, hemothorax,
pneumothorax (open, simple, tension), cardiac tamponade, rib fractures, flail chest and
commotio cordis.

001D04DA22D74E12A02859E162B75644.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the recognition and management of
chest trauma, including blunt versus penetrating mechanisms, open chest wound, impaled
object and pneumothorax (open and simple).

5AA125830AA04505BB2048F885527A30.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the pathophysiology,
assessment and management of bleeding.

11FF16604CD04C8FB4D9BE30571C3145.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on trauma pathophysiology,
assessment and management of the trauma patient, including trauma scoring, rapid transport,
destination issues and transport mode.

40BAB6766DF94729AF7CFD87B4C11D5A.description:
Trauma: Apply fundamental knowledge to provide basic emergency care and transportation based on
assessment findings for an acutely injured patient.

4486355D1C634233B5B7EABCB8EF2FC5.description:
Apply fundamental knowledge of the causes, pathophysiology and management of shock,
respiratory failure or arrest, cardiac failure or arrest and post‐resuscitation management.

506A596DC3F64EF293CB4018C7CE080C.description:
Use assessment information to recognize shock, respiratory failure or arrest and cardiac arrest
based on assessment findings and manage the emergency while awaiting additional
emergency response.

E9E09D7A03A74A588DC6682B330ADB61.description:
Shock and Resuscitation: Define and describe knowledge and skills in shock and resuscitation for the Emergency Medical
Technician (EMT).

38F124D462944093A49D8C317CD8CBE0.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of diseases of the eyes, ears, nose and throat.

65CF5F40F3624D59BA88DC9B01674D5C.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the recognition and management of
nose bleeds.

BAF3D317F1F64F688C2DA33A72E09D4A.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of non‐traumatic fractures.

A7D175E528BD486C9E2A4E4BE9AE5959.description: Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on gynecology infections.

B1A3BE70E9574C9AADA98E1458C8EE58.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
assessment findings and management of gynecology conditions, including vaginal bleeding
and sexual assault (to include appropriate emotional support).

690C7050189A49078470726120F87999.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of genitourinary/renal conditions, including

EF7018C4EF754D2EBFADE15EFD3042D7.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on blood pressure assessment in
hemodialysis patients.

12622D548E25419D8F2EA7D15B74423F.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of hematology conditions, including sickle cell
crisis and clotting disorders.

F190EC138A294C5398434584E6D9D9C1.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on pertussis, cystic fibrosis, pulmonary
embolism, pneumonia and viral respiratory infections.

02D6DFE67FD2420EB09452942C7F4716.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of respiratory conditions, including
epiglottitis, spontaneous pneumothorax, pulmonary edema, asthma, chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease, environmental/industrial exposure and toxic gas.

E5FEEA0CD7464006ABD3381344C3C84B.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, signs, symptoms and
management of respiratory emergencies, including those that affect the upper airway and
lower airway.

5F3F61B7B78A4901940946EB2A1E2D48.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of toxicology conditions, including inhaled
poisons, ingested poisons, injected poisons, absorbed poisons and alcohol intoxication and
withdrawal.

B09F1407C92547BEA8D8F92925CA53EB.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
carbon monoxide poisoning, nerve agent poisoning and how and when to contact a poison
control center.

9CFA9BF755F04F2CAD66F540BCFD351C.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on heart failure and hypertensive
emergencies.

DFCFAE6715DF49A6AD7E2B3B803A5180.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of cardiovascular conditions, including acute
coronary syndrome (angina pectoris, myocardial infarction), aortic aneurysm/dissection and
thromboembolism.

96622948CA9C4F46834A317989A6DC82.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the anatomy, signs, symptoms and
management of chest pain and cardiac arrest.

C0D9A962B67F4FCC98FC2E7153C03571.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the assessment and
management of psychiatric conditions, including acute psychosis, suicidal/risk and agitated
delirium.

BDAAD1C421724E7A85CCDF39D4485768.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the basic principles of the mental health
system.

C6EB447413714656A7C363142DA3608B.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of endocrine disorders, including acute
diabetic emergencies.

D0CF955A18F34F438DD6EAF298CDAAE1.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the assessment and management of a
patient who may have an infectious disease and how to decontaminate the ambulance and
equipment after treating a patient.

2C7B2C2C315E44FAAD8F76DC421BFB21.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of hypersensitivity disorders and/or
emergencies involving anaphylactic reactions.

A5D02BB37B654B94BC03382C1D4E0279.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge in the recognition and management of
shock and difficulty breathing related to anaphylactic reactions.

C498421BC0634E4BA158832F8991A27D.description: Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge of peritonitis and ulcerative diseases.

F9B03D2699424272B54327123C1B9A6D.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of abdominal and gastrointestinal disorders,
including acute and chronic gastrointestinal hemorrhage.

E0438EE707074798B6E900EAC2178291.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on the anatomy, physiology,
pathophysiology, assessment and management of neurology, including stroke/transient
ischemic attack, seizure, status epilepticus and headache.

D5245BD3D60A4AB9B1A2DA236154B21D.description:
Apply simple depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on pathophysiology, assessment and
management of a medical complaint (medical overview) to include transport mode and
destination decisions.

65C248E2E5E44EB7B9CB95A468774477.description:
Medicine: Apply fundamental knowledge to provide basic emergency care and transportation based on
assessment findings for an acutely ill patient.

1FCB955A93C0478795D15252CB69E80E.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on how and when to perform a
reassessment for all patient situations.

608C2F784F05455FB9FF25E13E61ABB1.description:
Use monitoring devices, within the scope of practice of the Emergency Medical Technician
(EMT), including (but not limited to) a 12‐lead electrocardiogram (ECG) setup and application
for electronic transmission and end tidal carbon dioxide monitoring and detection.

DC738CD1E3614B8E9797EF96A5EEAD6A.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on secondary assessment
techniques of physical examination, including respiratory system (presence of breath sounds),
cardiovascular system, neurological system, musculoskeletal system and all anatomical
regions.

89E7B7F652C44CD7A6A96952BC8BAE97.description:
Apply simple depth, simple breadth of knowledge on performing a secondary assessment,
including a rapid full‐body scan, focused assessment of pain and assessment of vital signs.

3D4AAAD41FEB44F2A31870A67CEA8784.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on history taking, including
investigation of the chief complaint, mechanism of injury/nature of illness, past medical
history, associated signs and symptoms and pertinent negatives.

314CA98F7C4C4E7EB58AEEA3611AF07B.description:
Apply fundamental depth, simple breadth of knowledge on the primary assessment for all
patient situations, including initial general impression, level of consciousness, ABCs (airway,
breathing, circulation), identifying life threats, assessment of vital functions and integration of
treatment/procedures needed to preserve life.

FB4AB199441A47B79AF4B2CE74AD70E4.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on scene size‐up, including
scene management and multiple patient situations.

64B18F1F64B441299E6452557CA52BC6.description:
Apply fundamental depth, foundational breadth of knowledge on scene management,
including the impact of the environment on patient care, addressing hazards, violence, the
need for additional or specialized resources and standard precautions.

F72CA2FB69CD40E488F1CE99C9A150D5.description: Apply complex depth, comprehensive breath of knowledge on scene safety.

DD17E40733E345719C9924B1DE07CF87.description:
